title: Facebook, Twitter CEOs to Defend Section 230 Protections
text: Oct.27 -- The heads of the big internet companies in the U.S. will defend legal protections granted to the industry on Wednesday when they testify before a congressional committee about social media's role in moderating speech online. Twitter Inc. Chief Executive Officer Jack Dorsey, who will appear before the Senate Commerce Committee virtually, will call Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act “the internet's most important law for free speech and safety,” and argue that repealing the law will lead to more policing of content, not less.

title: Cambridge Analytica Whistleblower: Facebook Hasn't Done Enough
text: Oct.27 -- Brittany Kaiser , co-founder at Own Your Data Foundation and whistleblower in the Facebook Inc. - Cambridge Analytica scandal, discusses whether social media platforms are ready to curb misinformation during the U.S. presidential election on "Bloomberg Technology."

title: Big Tech stocks are flashing buy signals, Jim Cramer says
text: "The charts, as interpreted by Katie Stockton, suggest that Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google and Microsoft ... are ready to roll higher," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Mark Zuckerberg And Jack Dorsey Are Gonna Have A Rotten Day As They Testify Before The Senate
text: The Twitter and Facebook CEOs must defend their companies' actions and argue against regulation even as Republicans have argued fiercely for more rules on social media.

title: Facebook, Google, Twitter CEOs to tell senators changing liability law will destroy how we communicate online
text: Facebook, Google, and Twitter's CEOs released prepared remarks ahead of Wednesday's hearing with Senate lawmakers that warned about negative implications of repealing the legal liability statute that their business models rely on.

title: Zuckerberg, Dorsey, Pichai to defend key law at Senate hearing Wednesday
text: Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg, Twitter Inc. CEO Jack Dorsey, and Alphabet Inc. CEO Sundar Pichai will mark their cases Wednesday to protect a crucial internet law that protects their social media sites from being held liable for the content posted by their users. Zuckerberg, however, is open to change.

title: Section 230: tech CEOs to defend key internet law before Congress
text: Facebook, Twitter and Google chiefs to argue against law's repeal amid unsubstantiated claims of anti-conservative bias

title: 'The American People No Longer Trust Big Tech' Says Sen. Blackburn
text: Senate Commerce Committee member Senator Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) joins Cheddar to discuss the upcoming tech hearing on Capitol Hill. Watch the hearing live on Cheddar tomorrow starting at 10AM ET.

title: Facebook, Twitter, Google CEOs to defend Section 230 before Senate panel
text: The law shields internet companies from liability for content posted by their users.

title: Big Tech Could Be In Big Trouble Next Year Under Biden—Even As Amazon, Apple, Facebook Prepare For Another Monster Quarter
text: Better-than-expected results on Thursday are likely to draw investor praise, but they could also provide fodder for heightened regulatory scrutiny.

title: Tech's legal shield under bipartisan attack as CEOs face lawmakers: 'There is more common ground than people realize,' Democrat says
text: It will be Facebook and Google's CEOs second time testifying before Congress this year alone, following July's House antitrust hearing.

title: Can Facebook Build On Recent Revenue Advances? Q3 Earnings And Conference Call Ahead
text: New all-time high aside, Facebook faces a couple potential headwinds, namely fresh controversy surrounding its content policies and antitrust concerns.

title: Alphabet, Facebook and other tech giants could benefit from surprise ad rebound in Q3, analysts predict
text: A recovery for the advertising market could mean bright things for the big tech companies' ads businesses when they report earnings later this week.

title: Can Big Techs Repeat Q2's Impressive Performances in Q3?
text: Several corporate behemoths will release earnings results this week, but the primary focus of market participants will be on five big tech brothers ??? Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOGL).

title: Apple and four other of the largest publicly traded companies are about to report earnings – what to watch
text: The five largest publicly traded companies in the U.S., including Apple and Amazon, are reporting earnings this week. Together they make up $7 trillion in market cap.

title: 3 Must-Watch Tech Earnings Reports This Week
text: These tech giants will provide key insight into the U.S. and global economy.
